I've seen parameters declared in Lean with four distinct kinds of parentheses: (), [], {}, and ⦃⦄. Are the exact differences between those documented anywhere? I tried searching #tpil for ⦃, but there weren't any results. So far, I think I figured out the following:

  • an argument declared with () needs to be provided explicitly
  • Lean will try to create a value for arguments declared with [] by using the typeclass mechanism
  • {} arguments are solved by unification
Here's what I wrote about brackets in my course: https://www.ma.imperial.ac.uk/~buzzard/xena/formalising-mathematics-2022/Part_B/brackets.html

Andrej Bauer gave the following answer on the proof assistant stack overflow that provides a very clear description of the difference between { } and {{ }}:
https://proofassistants.stackexchange.com/a/73/67

Kevin Buzzard said:

Here's what I wrote about brackets in my course: https://www.ma.imperial.ac.uk/~buzzard/xena/formalising-mathematics-2022/Part_B/brackets.html

Thanks, that cleared things up!
Jakub Kądziołka has marked this topic as resolved.
